Jim Gilbert <jg=
gilbert@...> wrote:
Louis,
Yoshitame looks like a correct reading=
, but sosho always leaves me wondering if there aren't other kanji that cou=
ld be "abbreviated" in the same way.  On the left side of the seppa dai the=
re are faint kaisho style mei that might read Myochin.  If that's what it i=
s I suppose that it could be the plate maker.  

There is a Yoshitame liste=
d in Wakayama and Haynes.  It's Haynes #H12160.  Personal name Seiunsha [=
=E9=9D=92=E9=9B=B2=E8=88=8E], worked in Kanazawa in Kaga, ca. 1800, "made t=
suba."

No mention of Myochin, but of course there were Myochin people maki=
ng iron plate tsuba in Kaga at that time.

Jim




  Hi there,

  I have a =
tsuba that I am trying to do some research on, it has an 
  elaborate grass=
script type writing on it that I have had 
  translated.   It turns out tha=
t it is a haiku peom written by 
  Baishitsu (1769-1852), and it means read=
s "Various impressions are 
  given to me every time the scenery of the sea=
son where the plum tree 
  blooms is seen". 

  There is also asignature wh=
ich I am told is the engraver of the 
  haiku poem, "Yoshitame".  Does anyo=
ne know who this person was or 
  what school he engraved for?

  Does anyo=
ne have information on this tsuba?

  Here is the link:

  http://www.japan=
eseswordcollector.com/tsuba.jpg

  Thanks in advance.

  Regards,

  Louis =
